body:
moved to 
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/6639

I'm not sure how it is the case that concact doesn't do backward shape inference. Everything works fine when you don't do expand_dims. The last code block that I posted *works* and that involves the shape having to be inferred from the concat. How is that working if concat doesn't do backward shape inference? If by some chance that fixes it though, then that's great. I would propose a fix, but I'm not up to speed enough on the C++ backend myself.

Reminsice, it's not that infer_shape_partial is merely not raising exceptions, it's that it's actually reporting the correct and complete shape information: it correctly infers that the output should be 5, 2, 3. If it is able to determine that that is the output shape, what else is missing that infer_shape chokes on?

On the TX2, you should compile MXNET with MSHADOW_USE_PASCAL=1 to get true fp16 kernels.  Sounds like you're doing that though.  Two possibilities then to help:

- Can you upgrade to cuDNNv6? MXNET with cuDNNv5.1 uses a different call (compared to v6) to set the convolution descriptor (one that does not explicitly set the compute precision).  Try this first.
- Can you run your experiment temporarily on a beefier PASCAL brick to check for a different behavior? There are subtle differences in the resources available to kernels run on a TX2 vs. say a TitanX-PASCAL. See the table at the bottom of https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CUDA.  I don't know if all algos are prepared to run on architecture sm_62.

And although this shouldn't affect your problem, you should add "62" to KNOWN_CUDA_ARCHS in ./Makefile (available in a recent push).  Remove other archs you don't care about to speed mxnet lib builds.
@sbodenstein when I try to use padding for convolution if mxnet is linked against mkl it crashes. just one more example of some buggy mkl related area.
@sbodenstein Could you provide some more details? Are you referring to the dimension of the tensor? If so, in what dimension does that crash?

please follow the signature and doc of numpy
https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.trunc.html
Why changing from -1 to 0?

`x2` shouldn't have been there, sorry. I originally had one more step in the example with x, but decided it added nothing to the demonstration of the error and simplified the example by removing it without fixing that part :p I fixed the code in the original message.

This is the complete output on the infer_shape:
```
>>> c.infer_shape()
__main__:1: UserWarning: Cannot decide shape for the following arguments (0s in shape means unknown dimensions). Consider providing them as input:
	
(None, None, None)
```

So it thinks there are zeros, but then doesn't report any arguments with zeros, just a blank line. It might not report any because the zeros do not appear in any any variables; it's after the broadcast. (If so, maybe that error message should be improved?) Regardless, the infer_shape_partial does not report any zeros either. I listed its output shape previously, but for completeness, here the full output of that call:
```
>>> c.infer_shape_partial()
([(1, 3)], [(5, 2, 3)], [])
```
As you can see, everything is complete, with no zeros.

Perhaps this result is because infer_shape_partial is printing out what it expects the output to be, before everything is checked, but then the information doesn't get passed down anyway? That would coincide with what piiswong said about concat not doing the backward part of the shape; however, I don't think the problem is with concat, because as I noted, it was fine with the last code block I showed which required concat pushing back information to the broadcast as well. It seems like it's expand_dims that's the culprit since it's the only thing between those two.

I changed to:
```
yc = np.array(my_data[:,0]-np.mean(my_data[:,0]))
label = np.transpose(np.tile(yc,(2,1)))
```

and then ran with num_hidden = 2, but this just produces two copies of the num_hidden = 1 case.

`reshape` op have two shape params: shape and target_shape

`shape` will auto infer shape by setting as `-1`

`target_shape` will auto infer shape by setting as `0`

this is **Reshape** construct in cpp-package:

```cpp
inline Symbol Reshape(Symbol data,
                      Shape shape = Shape(),
                      bool reverse = false,
                      Shape target_shape = Shape(0,0),
                      bool keep_highest = false) {
  return Operator("Reshape")
           .SetParam("shape", shape)
           .SetParam("reverse", reverse)
           .SetParam("target_shape", target_shape)
           .SetParam("keep_highest", keep_highest)
           .SetInput("data", data)
           .CreateSymbol();
```

I check the git log of `reshape` op, I found the order of `shape` and `target_shape` had changed. so this bug occurs.
@ysh329 have you solved it ?

haha, I fixed the bugs. Now my distribution training system (based on mxnet0.8.0) can support partial weight update now!
@mli @piiswrong
#3625 has been fixed. I am closing this now. Feel free to reopen.
I had a similar issue in #5568 with different ops but same problem (failed infer_shape but all results present in infer_shape_partial). In my issue the problem is in zeros((0, 0)).

我傻逼！
size of `h` changed....
Both fixed according to numpy. Somehow I did not immediately realize exact mirror of numpy was the purpose here.

@jmacglashan There are two problems:
1. `c = mx.sym.concat(x, y3, dim=1)` should be `c = mx.sym.concat(x, y3, dim=0)`
1. When you wrote `y2 = mx.sym.broadcast_axis(y, axis=0, size=0)`, this leaves an internal node with undetermined output shapes (0 in the first dim). As MXNet does not allow empty tensors, this is still treated as `infer_shape` failure even though arg shapes and output shapes can be deduced.

Anyhow, we can certainly improve the error message to let users have more information to debug.

Please also include this sentence:
The truncated value of the scalar x is the nearest integer i which is closer to zero than x is. In short, the fractional part of the signed number x is discarded.
@jmacglashan Looks like its expand_dims that's not doing backward shape infer. You can try fix the infer_shape function

I'm having the same error.
Installed latest mxnet with pip.

CentOS Linux release 7.3.1611 (Core) 
Python 3.6.1
Cuda compilation tools, release 8.0, V8.0.61

@jmacglashan I see. I went through the InferShape pass in gdb and noticed the output of broadcast_axis's shape has 0 in the first dim at the end of the pass, which should have been back-inferred by the output of expand_dims. I can help by submitting a PR to fix this.

This will help a lot. Has this been merged upstream and are binaries ready?

Also, people have really started to use RDS files or RData.  Extending this functionality to RDS would be huge if you can.

@jaredlander This has been merged in #6494 .

After `mx.serialize`, it is basically the R object, you can save into RDS as you like.
MXNet only has arctan symbol, you can use CustomOp to implement arctan2.

> > @@ -316,6 +316,12 @@ inline bool ExpandDimShape(const nnvm::NodeAttrs& attrs,
>    ret[param.axis] = 1;
>    for (index_t i = param.axis+1; i < ret.ndim(); ++i) ret[i] = shp[i-1];
>    SHAPE_ASSIGN_CHECK(*out_attrs, 0, ret);
> +
>
> One problem I noticed here is that param.axis of type index_t. When users
> enter a meaningful negative number for the axis, it would be interpreted as
> a very big unsigned int, which would result in CHECK_LE failure in line
> 312. Do you think it's a good idea to change param.axis from type index_t
> to int and allow negative axis input?

Actually it's `mx.symbol.Concat` that works properly, `mx.symbol.concat` is also causing issue: 

```
> x1 <- mx.symbol.Variable("data1")
> x2 <- mx.symbol.Variable("data2")
> y <- mx.symbol.concat(data=c(x1, x2), num.args = 2)
Error in mx.varg.symbol.concat(list(...)) : 
  ./base.h:271: RCheck failed: TYPEOF(val) == INTSXP || TYPEOF(val) == REALSXP Only accept integer vectors or simple types
```

Sorry for the confusion!
Turned out floor and ceil were the only ones that needed improvement, out of rounding operators at least

We are thinking of more modular approach, like introducing another flag MXNET_USE_GPU, this would have an inline function defined that will be common for both CUDA and HIP implementations, we would separate the inline function implementations into two different files specific to CUDA and HIP, based on the flag that is defined, the preprocessor would expand the inline function into the corresponding implementation. We think that this approach would help us in future to separate the implentation into different backends(HIP,CUDA,...). Please comment.

You can install both cuda 7.5 and cuda 8 on the same computer. I install driver and cuda using the run file.

ok. i suggest make sure which line cause this error, maybe it's not in your post code. or you can use minimum the symbol code to debug that.

I have a simmilar question to itijyou. Is there an assignment analog to the ndarray.take function ? 
For example, lets take a simple case of sorting, where we take an array 'a', and attempt to set the 4 lowest valued indices to 0. The last step 'a[c] = 0' does not throw an error, however it also does not perform the assignment to 'a'.

python
>>> import mxnet as mx
>>> import numpy as np
>>> a = mx.nd.array(np.array([1,4,6,2,4,5,6,2]))
>>> a.asnumpy()
array([ 1.,  4.,  6.,  2.,  4.,  5.,  6.,  2.], dtype=float32)

#### sort the array and find the indices of the 4 lowest valued entries
>>> b = mx.nd.argsort(a)
>>> b.asnumpy()
array([ 0.,  3.,  7.,  1.,  4.,  5.,  2.,  6.], dtype=float32)
>>> c=b[0:4]
>>> c.asnumpy()
array([ 0.,  3.,  7.,  1.], dtype=float32)

####  ndarray.take() can be used to read the values in 'a' corresponding to the indices in 'c'
>>> d = mx.nd.take(a,c)
>>> d.asnumpy()
array([ 1.,  2.,  2.,  4.], dtype=float32)

#### How do we write to 'a' at the indices given by 'c'. Following does not work:
>>> a[c] = 0
>>> a.asnumpy()
array([ 1.,  4.,  6.,  2.,  4.,  5.,  6.,  2.], dtype=float32)

Any help or alternative would be helpful. The only alternative I can think of is the following, which is ugly and does not really work well if the values in 'a' are not unique:

#### select the 4th smallest element
>>> c=b[4]
>>> c.asnumpy()
array([ 4.], dtype=float32)
>>> d = mx.nd.take(a,c)
>>> d.asnumpy()
array([ 4.], dtype=float32)

#### create a binary mask of all elements larger than the 4th smallest element
>>> mask = a > d
>>> mask.asnumpy()
array([ 0.,  0.,  1.,  0.,  0.,  1.,  1.,  0.], dtype=float32)
>>> mask = 1-mask
>>> mask.asnumpy()
array([ 1.,  1.,  0.,  1.,  1.,  0.,  0.,  1.], dtype=float32)
>>> e = a * mask
>>> e.asnumpy()
array([ 1.,  4.,  0.,  2.,  4.,  0.,  0.,  2.], dtype=float32)

As you see, there is an extra '4' in the 'e' result.

My real life application is to perform hard negative sampling based on the loss values. For example, I have a 60x40 loss matrix, and I need to find the top 100 loss values, and set the gradients corresponding to the rest to 0. I can do this easily in numpy but would prefere a pure mx.ndarray based solution.

@ykim362: 

```
a = mx.sym.Activation(act_type="relu", data = mx.sym.Variable('a'))
e = a.bind(mx.cpu(), {'a': mx.nd.array([1,2])})
y = e.forward()
```
produces:
```
[18:26:50] /mxnet/dmlc-core/include/dmlc/logging.h:304: [18:26:50] /mxnet/nnvm/include/nnvm/tuple.h:446: Check failed: dim == static_cast<int>(ndim()) (4 vs. 1) dimension do not match target dimension 4 vs 1

@piiswrong Hi Eric, could you guys review and merge this PR?

Thanks, @sbodenstein !

I will investigate the case.

Never mind.... Since no one will probably answer this...., in case anyone has this issue in the future:
just pass in an extra parameter into the epoch end callback function for your metric or metrics list and call get_name_value() on that.

@sbodenstein ,
Currently, MKL relu is only enabled for 2D, 3D and 4D tensors.
Even though 1D tensor can be supported by MKL, it hasn't been enabled, yet. Above example is 1D tensor case.

I will fix two and make a pull request.
(1) Correctly support 1D tensor.
(2) In the case of non-supported dimensions (higher than 4D), make use of the default 3rd party library.

I will also look into the way how to support higher than 4-d tensors.

I am sorry for the inconvenience.
Thanks.

The issue with CTC Loss is now resolved (model can be loaded) when using the snapshot artifact under OS X,

```
libraryDependencies += "ml.dmlc.mxnet" % "mxnet-full_2.11-osx-x86_64-cpu" % "0.10.0-SNAPSHOT"
```

Thank you for a quick response!
Yes, do test with cudnn 6. Now that Dick mentioned it I remember that without it you can't get true fp16 even with use_pascal flag set.

@tornadomeet Fact is that if I remove the the last convolution layer, named "deconv1_1", making the output shape smaller than the input, the algorithm could run perfectly. Otherwise, it output an error. I use only one batch data for testing this.

@dragonhyq  Scalapkg now use macro to automatically generate the symbol(operator, layer), so no needs to add symbols by hand. That's why you can not find the definition of FullyConnected in source code.

@Ldpe2G Thanks for your reply. So, what would be the best way to know what operations are available for a Symbol object since there is no documentation/source-code for that? I can go through the list that pops up in IntelliJ after writing `Symbol` to see what's there and just choose the one I want, but is there a better way?

@dragonhyq 
There are two ways: 
you can refer to the python doc: http://mxnet.io/api/python/symbol.html#api-reference,
or refer to the C++ source code: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/src/operator

okey, looks like with pip it always comes without GPU support

for compilation from sources, `python3 setup.py install` was not overwriting existing  pip-installed package somehow. 

After I manually deleted mxnet from dist-packages, and re-installed from sources it is working.

Would be nice to have GPU-enabled version from pip though..

Concat() in op.h

I think this is done now. 
I added an additional flag to the configs USE_LAPACK which is 1 by default. So there is always an easy option to turn it off. 

In the default mode (USE_LAPACK=1), it will add lapack support whenever we use one of the blas distributions that contain lapack (apple/atlas/openblas/mkl). Concerning Ubuntu, the state is that 14.04 and 16.04 are almost equivalent: In both cases, lapack is part of the official packages. The difference is that on 14.04, installing openblas will not automatically install the lapack library while in 16.04 it does. In both cases, 
sudo apt-get install -y libopenblas-dev liblapack-dev
will get all necessary pieces (just that in 16.04 there would be no need for referencing liblapack explicitly, but it will work either way). Tested that explicitly on the different images. 
So our docker container can happily stay at 14.04 with the small change that it also installs liblapack-dev now. No need to migrate to 16.04. 

In my most recent run, one of the travis-ci builds times out when doing some tests on neural networks (not related to the new functionalities herein). Seen this happen in the past from time to time, may be we want to give this tests a bit more time by default. So all is clean.

I will work on integrating cuda support for these operators  as soon as this PR gets integrated. Don't want to pile up more stuff on top of this. This will result in a small bit of internal restructuring. The goal would be to provide a common internal abstraction layer that handles the different DTypes and CPU vs. GPU automatically for the blas3/lapack functions (as suggested by the reviews). 
Let me know what you think.

- Alternatively, could we merge this PR with CPU code first so that I could submit my PRs on tensors? I'll need to put more LAPACK interfaces in 'c_lapack_api.h'.

- A tiny clarification: on Ubuntu 16.04 the official build 'libopenblas.so' mangled in both BLAS/LAPACK symbols but the one on 14.04 only BLAS symbols. Always linking against the Netlib's version is a viable way to get it work. It really just depends on what we intend to do.
This was what I wanted to say as well: First merge this PR with CPU code before adding anything else.
You're welcome. Close this issue for now.

[Symbol-FullyConnected](http://mxnet.io/api/python/symbol.html#mxnet.symbol.FullyConnected)

num_hidden (int, required) – Number of hidden nodes of the output. So when set num_hidden = 2, you are expecting two outputs instead of one for each data instance.

Let's either make USE_LAPACK=0 by default or automatically turn it of when we cannot detect lapack.

In short, we shouldn't break build for people who don't have lapack installed.
